connector.description: Receive traps and poll SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) capable devices.

camel.sink.path.host.name: camel.sink.path.host
camel.sink.path.host.description: Hostname of the SNMP enabled device

camel.sink.path.port.name: camel.sink.path.port
camel.sink.path.port.description: Port number of the SNMP enabled device

camel.sink.endpoint.oids.name: camel.sink.endpoint.oids
camel.sink.endpoint.oids.description: Defines which values you are interested in. Please have a look at the Wikipedia to get a better understanding. You may provide a single OID or a coma separated list of OIDs. Example: oids=1.3.6.1.2.1.1.3.0,1.3.6.1.2.1.25.3.2.1.5.1,1.3.6.1.2.1.25.3.5.1.1.1,1.3.6.1.2.1.43.5.1.1.11.1

camel.sink.endpoint.protocol.name: camel.sink.endpoint.protocol
camel.sink.endpoint.protocol.description: Here you can select which protocol to use. You can use either udp or tcp. One of: [tcp] [udp]

camel.sink.endpoint.retries.name: camel.sink.endpoint.retries
camel.sink.endpoint.retries.description: Defines how often a retry is made before canceling the request.

camel.sink.endpoint.snmpCommunity.name: camel.sink.endpoint.snmpCommunity
camel.sink.endpoint.snmpCommunity.description: Sets the community octet string for the snmp request.

camel.sink.endpoint.snmpContextEngineId.name: camel.sink.endpoint.snmpContextEngineId
camel.sink.endpoint.snmpContextEngineId.description: Sets the context engine ID field of the scoped PDU.

camel.sink.endpoint.snmpContextName.name: camel.sink.endpoint.snmpContextName
camel.sink.endpoint.snmpContextName.description: Sets the context name field of this scoped PDU.

camel.sink.endpoint.snmpVersion.name: camel.sink.endpoint.snmpVersion
camel.sink.endpoint.snmpVersion.description: Sets the snmp version for the request. The value 0 means SNMPv1, 1 means SNMPv2c, and the value 3 means SNMPv3 One of: [0] [1] [3]

camel.sink.endpoint.timeout.name: camel.sink.endpoint.timeout
camel.sink.endpoint.timeout.description: Sets the timeout value for the request in millis.

camel.sink.endpoint.type.name: camel.sink.endpoint.type
camel.sink.endpoint.type.description: Which operation to perform such as poll, trap, etc. One of: [TRAP] [POLL] [GET_NEXT]

camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.name: camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer
camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.sink.endpoint.authenticationPassph.name: camel.sink.endpoint.authenticationPassphrase
camel.sink.endpoint.authenticationPassph.description: The authentication passphrase. If not null, authenticationProtocol must also be not null. RFC3414 11.2 requires passphrases to have a minimum length of 8 bytes. If the length of authenticationPassphrase is less than 8 bytes an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

camel.sink.endpoint.authenticationProtoc.name: camel.sink.endpoint.authenticationProtocol
camel.sink.endpoint.authenticationProtoc.description: Authentication protocol to use if security level is set to enable authentication The possible values are: MD5, SHA1 One of: [MD5] [SHA1]

camel.sink.endpoint.privacyPassphrase.name: camel.sink.endpoint.privacyPassphrase
camel.sink.endpoint.privacyPassphrase.description: The privacy passphrase. If not null, privacyProtocol must also be not null. RFC3414 11.2 requires passphrases to have a minimum length of 8 bytes. If the length of authenticationPassphrase is less than 8 bytes an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

camel.sink.endpoint.privacyProtocol.name: camel.sink.endpoint.privacyProtocol
camel.sink.endpoint.privacyProtocol.description: The privacy protocol ID to be associated with this user. If set to null, this user only supports unencrypted messages.

camel.sink.endpoint.securityLevel.name: camel.sink.endpoint.securityLevel
camel.sink.endpoint.securityLevel.description: Sets the security level for this target. The supplied security level must be supported by the security model dependent information associated with the security name set for this target. The value 1 means: No authentication and no encryption. Anyone can create and read messages with this security level The value 2 means: Authentication and no encryption. Only the one with the right authentication key can create messages with this security level, but anyone can read the contents of the message. The value 3 means: Authentication and encryption. Only the one with the right authentication key can create messages with this security level, and only the one with the right encryption/decryption key can read the contents of the message. One of: [1] [2] [3]

camel.sink.endpoint.securityName.name: camel.sink.endpoint.securityName
camel.sink.endpoint.securityName.description: Sets the security name to be used with this target.

camel.component.snmp.lazyStartProducer.name: camel.component.snmp.lazyStartProducer
camel.component.snmp.lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.component.snmp.autowiredEnabled.name: camel.component.snmp.autowiredEnabled
camel.component.snmp.autowiredEnabled.description: Whether autowiring is enabled. This is used for automatic autowiring options (the option must be marked as autowired) by looking up in the registry to find if there is a single instance of matching type, which then gets configured on the component. This can be used for automatic configuring JDBC data sources, JMS connection factories, AWS Clients, etc.
